Robbie_Fulks:
{{Short description|American singer-songwriter}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = Robbie Fulks | background = solo_singer | image = Robbie-fulks.jpg | image_size = | caption = Fulks in 2011 | birth_name = Robert William Fulks{{cite web |url=https://www.ascap.com/repertory#/ace/search/workID/890366043 |title=A MIRACLE |website=ASCAP |publisher=American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers |access-date=March 13, 2023 |archive-date=March 30, 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190330145422/https://www.ascap.com/repertory#/ace/search/workID/890366043 |url-status=live }} | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1963|03|25|mf=y}} | birth_place = [[York, Pennsylvania|York]], [[Pennsylvania]], [[United States|U.S.]] |origin = [[North Carolina]] | genre = Singer-songwriter
Neo-traditionalist country
[[Alternative country]]

Jenny Scheinman
Robbie Gjersoe }} '''Robert William "Robbie" Fulks''' (born March 25, 1963) is an American [[alternative country]] singer-songwriter, instrumentalist and long-time resident of [[Chicago, Illinois]].{{cite journal|last1=Margasak|first1=Peter|title=Robbie Fulks: Country Without Borders|journal=Journal of Country Music|date=5 June 2003|url=http://www.cmt.com/news/1472313/robbie-fulks-country-without-borders/|publisher=[[Country Music Hall of Fame]]|access-date=14 December 2016|archive-date=3 May 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160503175907/http://www.cmt.com/news/1472313/robbie-fulks-country-without-borders/|url-status=dead}}{{cite news|last1=Bellware|first1=Kim|title=Robbie Fulks Talks Dinner Guests, Baseball Bullies And Making Country Music As A City-Dweller|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/09/05/robbie-fulks-interview-_n_3881378.html|work=[[The Huffington Post]]|date=6 September 2013|access-date=27 December 2013|archive-date=28 December 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131228061723/http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/09/05/robbie-fulks-interview-_n_3881378.html|url-status=live}} He has released 15 albums over a career spanning more than 30 years.{{cite news|title=Robbie Fulks|url=http://www.nbc.com/last-call-with-carson-daly/video/robbie-fulks/n44452/|work=[[Last Call with Carson Daly]]|date=12 December 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140122202334/http://www.nbc.com/last-call-with-carson-daly/video/robbie-fulks/n44452/|archive-date=22 January 2014}} His 2016 record ''[[Upland Stories]]'' was nominated for a [[Grammy Award|Grammy]] for [[Grammy Award for Best Folk Album|Best Folk Album]] and the song "Alabama at Night" was nominated for a Grammy for [[Grammy Award for Best American Roots Song|Best American Roots Song]].{{cite news|title=2017 Grammy Awards: Complete list of nominees|url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/music/la-et-ms-grammys-2017-nominations-winners-list-20161205-story.html|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=6 December 2016|access-date=14 December 2016|archive-date=14 January 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170114165448/http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/music/la-et-ms-grammys-2017-nominations-winners-list-20161205-story.html|url-status=live}} == Early life == Fulks was born in [[York, Pennsylvania|York]], [[Pennsylvania]], the son of a school teacher father. He grew up in small towns in southeastern [[Pennsylvania]], the [[Blue Ridge Mountains]] area of [[Virginia]], and the [[Piedmont (United States)|Piedmont]] region of [[North Carolina]]. Fulks's family moved often when he was young, eventually settling in North Carolina when he was 12, and Fulks considers North Carolina his childhood home.{{cite news|last1=Brown|first1=Shannon|title=A Chat with Robbie Fulks: Country's Kingpin of Clever|url=http://www.outlawmagazine.com/2012/06/24/a-chat-with-robbie-fulks-countrys-kingpin-of-clever/|work=Outlaw Magazine|date=24 June 2012|access-date=14 December 2016|archive-date=20 December 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161220131127/http://www.outlawmagazine.com/2012/06/24/a-chat-with-robbie-fulks-countrys-kingpin-of-clever/|url-status=live}} He has a younger brother named Jubal. Fulks was exposed to music through his family in which everyone played a different musical instrument, from his Aunt Stella on banjo, his Aunt Mildred on violin and his mother on autoharp, to his father playing guitar.{{cite web|title=Robbie Fulks|url=http://chicagotonight.wttw.com/2014/01/09/robbie-fulks|work=WTTW Chicago Tonight|format=TV interview|date=9 January 2014|access-date=10 January 2014|archive-date=10 January 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140110214253/http://chicagotonight.wttw.com/2014/01/09/robbie-fulks|url-status=live}} Fulks picked up his aunt's banjo when he was six and started playing guitar at age 11.{{cite news|last1=Schram|first1=Dan|title=Video: Robbie Fulks Returns to Durham with New Autobiographical Songs|url=http://www.indyweek.com/music/archives/2016/06/23/video-robbie-fulks-returns-to-durham-with-autobiographical-new-songs|work=[[Indy Week]]|date=23 June 2016|access-date=14 December 2016|archive-date=20 December 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161220113134/http://www.indyweek.com/music/archives/2016/06/23/video-robbie-fulks-returns-to-durham-with-autobiographical-new-songs|url-status=live}} He graduated from [[Carolina Friends School]] in 1980 at the age of 17 and moved to New York City, where he attended [[Columbia College, Columbia University]] with the class of 1984.{{Cite web |date=2020-08-06 |title=Take Five with Adam Van Doren '84, GSAPP'89 |url=https://www.college.columbia.edu/cct/latest/take-five/take-five-adam-van-doren-84-gsapp89 |access-date=2022-06-01 |website=Columbia College Today |language=en |archive-date=2022-06-01 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220601091632/https://www.college.columbia.edu/cct/latest/take-five/take-five-adam-van-doren-84-gsapp89 |url-status=live }} == Career == While at [[Columbia University]], Fulks often played at [[Gerdes Folk City]] and other places in [[Greenwich Village]]. He also performed on campus in places such as the [[Postcrypt Coffeehouse]]. He eventually dropped out of college after two years to pursue music full time. === Chicago === Fulks moved to Chicago in 1983 and started teaching at Chicago's [[Old Town School of Folk Music]]. In 1987, he joined [[The Special Consensus]] Bluegrass Band, where he showcased his unique guitar flatpicking style. In the early 1990s he performed in the musical ''Woody Guthrie's American Song''.{{cite web|last=Huey|first=Steve|title=Robbie Fulks – Biography|url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/robbie-fulks-mn0000285164/biography|work=All Music|publisher=All Media Network, LLC.|access-date=December 28, 2013|archive-date=November 23, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131123013204/http://www.allmusic.com/artist/robbie-fulks-mn0000285164/biography|url-status=live}} He also recorded his original compositions. Many of his early tracks were engineered by [[Steve Albini]], and the Chicago punk-country label [[Bloodshot Records]] began releasing them in 1993.{{cite journal|last=Ray|first=Linda|title=The Long Way Around – Feature: Robbie Fulks|url=http://archives.nodepression.com/1997/09/it-drawled-from-the-mouth/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130606041414/http://archives.nodepression.com/1997/09/it-drawled-from-the-mouth/|archive-date=June 6, 2013|journal=No Depression Magazine|access-date=December 28, 2013|issue=11|date=September–October 1997}} === Nashville === While living in Chicago, Fulks worked for four years as a country songwriter, mainly for Music Row publisher API. His solo debut album, ''Country Love Songs'', engineered by [[Steve Albini]], was released on Bloodshot Records in 1996 and received positive reviews. The Skeletons, members of whom later formed the band [[The Morells]], played on most of the tracks and [[Tom Brumley]] and [[Buck Owens]] also featured. ''Country Love Songs'' was followed in 1997 by ''South Mouth'', which confirmed Fulks's retro-alternative image. Fans had grown used to his rough and sparse sound, but his third album, 1998's ''Let's Kill Saturday Night'', on [[Geffen Records]],{{cite web|last=Walker|first=Jesse|title=Soundbite: Music Man|url=http://reason.com/archives/2000/05/01/soundbite-music-man|work=Reason.com|publisher=Reason Foundation|access-date=December 27, 2013|date=May 2000|archive-date=November 11, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131111103225/http://reason.com/archives/2000/05/01/soundbite-music-man|url-status=live}}{{cite news|last=Strauss|first=Neil|title=A Major Merger Shakes Up the World of Rock|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/21/arts/a-major-merger-shakes-up-the-world-of-rock.html?pagewanted=all&src=pm|access-date=December 28, 2013|newspaper=The New York Times|date=December 21, 1998|archive-date=January 16, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140116152111/http://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/21/arts/a-major-merger-shakes-up-the-world-of-rock.html?pagewanted=all&src=pm|url-status=live}} was different. Fulks recorded it during the spring of 1998 in Nashville with producer Rick Will, and the album included performances by [[Lucinda Williams]], [[Sam Bush]], [[Bill Lloyd (country musician)|Bill Lloyd]], and [[Al Anderson (NRBQ)|Al Anderson]], as well as guitarist Rob Gjersoe ([[Jimmie Dale Gilmore]]), bassist Lorne Rall, and drummer Dan Massey. Geffen Records disbanded shortly after the release of the record and Fulks, finding himself without a label, started his own company, Boondoggle Records, and released an album of previously unreleased material called ''The Very Best of Robbie Fulks''. He also licenses his music for distribution by Bloodshot. == Output == {{Quote box |quote = I called it ''Gone Away Backward'' because it's a phrase from the Bible… I stumbled on the phrase later in the evolution of the record when I was looking around for a title. I think it's a nice piquant phrase that has three good, strong, mellifluous words in it. As far as the backwardness of the record, I think it goes backward in terms of nostalgia for the past – bittersweet nostalgia for the past – as well as the recession having knocked everything backwards for people. In that sense, it's not an album about the past, it's an album about now. |source = "Interview with Robbie Fulks about 'Gone Away Backward'"
by Kim Ruehl, ''No Depression Magazine'' (September 18, 2013) |width = 30% |align = right }} In 2001 he released ''Couples in Trouble'', a dark, brooding, and decidedly non-country album, and ''13 Hillbilly Giants'', a collection of covers of classic country numbers, both obscure and well known. Both records were released by Bloodshot Records. Also in 2001, Fulks was an inaugural member of the judging panel for the Independent Music Awards, which supported independent artists.{{cite web|title=Past Judges for the Independent Music Awards|url=http://www.independentmusicawards.com/ima_new/pastjudges.asp|work=Independent Music Awards|access-date=December 27, 2013|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110713024722/http://www.independentmusicawards.com/ima_new/pastjudges.asp|archive-date=July 13, 2011}} Fulks did not release another album until 2005. ''Georgia Hard'' on [[Yep Roc Records]] was a return to his county roots, and was notable for its use of long-time Nashville talent such as [[Lloyd Green]], Hank Singer, [[Dennis Crouch (bassist)|Dennis Crouch]], and [[Dallas Wayne]]. He also released a novelty single called "Fountains of Wayne Hotline," in which he imagined the power pop band [[Fountains of Wayne]] having a hotline that struggling songwriters could call for help with their song structure. In April 2007, Fulks released a 2-CD album, ''Revenge!'' (also on Yep Roc Records), which consisted mainly of live concert recordings of older songs and included some new material. One disc, labeled ''Standing'', featured a full-band sound, while the second disc, ''Sitting,'' consisted of Fulks solo with little or no musical accompaniment. ''Standing'' opens with the tongue-in-cheek studio track "We're on the Road", which describes life on tour and simulates a telephone call to Fulks from Yep Roc Records President Glenn Dicker, demanding a new record and denigrating the sales performance of the "path-breaking, not chart-breaking" album ''Georgia Hard.'' In 2009, Fulks released an alphabetically organized collection of 50 songs via his website, a compilation called ''50-Vc. Doberman.''{{cite news|last=Ratliff|first=Ben|title=Playlist: Expansive Pop, Hypnotic Jazz, Surprising Metal|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/03/08/arts/music/08play.html?_r=0|access-date=December 28, 2013|newspaper=The New York Times|date=March 4, 2009|archive-date=April 13, 2023|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230413203308/https://www.nytimes.com/2009/03/08/arts/music/08play.html?_r=0|url-status=live}} He noted that this method, and electronic-only release in general, was not typical of musicians who worked in his genre. In 2010, Fulks released his next album, ''Happy: Robbie Fulks Plays the Music of Michael Jackson,'' on Yep Roc Records, in which he covered some of Jackson's songs as a tribute. He had been working on the album since 2005.{{cite web|last=Guarino|first=Mark|title=Robbie Fulks Reinterprets Michael Jackson's Music in New Album, "Happy"|url=http://www.chicagomag.com/Chicago-Magazine/June-2010/Robbie-Fulks-Reinterprets-Michael-Jacksons-Music-in-New-Album-Happy/|work=Chicago Magazine|access-date=December 28, 2013|date=May 28, 2010|archive-date=December 30, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131230235756/http://www.chicagomag.com/Chicago-Magazine/June-2010/Robbie-Fulks-Reinterprets-Michael-Jacksons-Music-in-New-Album-Happy/|url-status=live}}{{cite web|last=Fontenot|first=Elvis|title=Robbie Fulks – "Happy"|url=http://www.nodepression.com/profiles/blogs/robbie-fulks-happy|work=No Depression|access-date=December 28, 2013|date=April 8, 2010|archive-date=December 30, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131230234311/http://www.nodepression.com/profiles/blogs/robbie-fulks-happy|url-status=live}} In 2013, Fulks released ''Gone Away Backward,'' an acoustic album recorded and mixed by [[Steve Albini]] and released on Bloodshot Records. It was his first release on that label since 2001's ''13 Hillbilly Giants.'' The album featured banjo, mandolin, fiddle, and upright bass.{{cite web|last=McGovern|first=Kyle|title=Stream Robbie Fulks' Small-Town Folk Epic 'Gone Away Backward':Newest full-length from 50-year-old tunesmith arrives August 27|url=https://www.spin.com/2013/08/robbie-fulks-gone-away-backward-bloodshot-records-album-stream/|work=Spin magazine|publisher=Spin Music, a division of SpinMedia|access-date=December 27, 2013|format=audio stream|date=August 20, 2013|archive-date=April 5, 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150405042017/http://www.spin.com/2013/08/robbie-fulks-gone-away-backward-bloodshot-records-album-stream/|url-status=live}} He said one of the songs, "That's Where I'm From", was autobiographical.{{cite web|last=Ruehl|first=Kim|title=Interview with Robbie Fulks about 'Gone Away Backward'|url=http://www.nodepression.com/profiles/blogs/interview-with-robbie-fulks-about-gone-away-backward|work=No Depression Magazine|access-date=December 28, 2013|date=September 18, 2013|archive-date=December 30, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131230235818/http://www.nodepression.com/profiles/blogs/interview-with-robbie-fulks-about-gone-away-backward|url-status=live}} Four songs from ''50-Vc Doberman'' were the genesis of ''Gone Away Backward:''{{cite web|last=Mateer|first=Chris|title=Robbie Fulks Spins His Tale Of "Gone Away Backward" (Interview)|url=http://www.nodepression.com/profiles/blogs/interview-robbie-fulks-spins-his-tale-of-gone-away-backward|archive-url=https://archive.today/20131228182602/http://www.nodepression.com/profiles/blogs/interview-robbie-fulks-spins-his-tale-of-gone-away-backward|url-status=dead|archive-date=December 28, 2013|work=No Depression|access-date=December 28, 2013|date=December 4, 2013}} the title came from the [[Book of Isaiah]].{{cite web|title=Isaiah: Isa.1|url=http://quod.lib.umich.edu/cgi/k/kjv/kjv-idx?type=DIV1&byte=2594466|work=Bible, King James Version|access-date=January 10, 2014|archive-date=November 27, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131127171900/http://quod.lib.umich.edu/cgi/k/kjv/kjv-idx?type=DIV1&byte=2594466|url-status=live}} Fulks said that ''Gone Away Backward'' went back to his roots as a musician. The stylistic choice was a good fit with the other musicians who appeared on the recording, Robbie Gjersoe, Jenny Scheinman, and Mike Bub. They recorded live without any overdubbing or elaborate production and laid down around 25 songs in three days.{{cite web|title=Robbie Fulks on World Cafe|url=https://www.npr.org/blogs/world-cafe/2014/01/21/264529547/robbie-fulks-on-world-cafe|work=WXPN|publisher=NPR|access-date=January 23, 2014|date=January 21, 2014|archive-date=January 22, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140122060318/http://www.npr.org/blogs/world-cafe/2014/01/21/264529547/robbie-fulks-on-world-cafe|url-status=live}} In 2014, Fulks joined members of [[The Mekons]], dubbed "mini-Mekons", on a trip to write and record on the island of [[Jura, Scotland|Jura]] in Scotland. The resulting record, ''Jura'', was released in November 2015 and consisted of traditional songs and original songs written on the trip.{{cite news|last1=Moss|first1=Marissa R.|title=Hear Robbie Fulks and Cowpunkers the Mekons' Wild 'Beaten and Broken'|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/hear-robbie-fulks-and-cowpunkers-the-mekons-wild-beaten-and-broken-20151105|access-date=November 21, 2015|work=[[Rolling Stone (magazine)|Rolling Stone]]|date=November 5, 2015|archive-date=November 7, 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151107194607/http://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/hear-robbie-fulks-and-cowpunkers-the-mekons-wild-beaten-and-broken-20151105|url-status=live}} In April 2016, he released ''[[Upland Stories]],''{{cite web|last1=Odenkirk|first1=Bob|title=The First Bob Odenkirk Interview Quiz Challenge Show: Robbie Fulks|url=http://www.funnyordie.com/videos/9d698566ec/the-first-bob-odenkirk-interview-quiz-challenge-show-robbie-fulks|website=[[Funny or Die]]|access-date=March 10, 2016|date=March 9, 2016|archive-date=March 11, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160311064656/http://www.funnyordie.com/videos/9d698566ec/the-first-bob-odenkirk-interview-quiz-challenge-show-robbie-fulks|url-status=live}} and the album was nominated for a 2017 Grammy Award for best folk album. The opening track, "Alabama at Night", was nominated for best American roots song.{{Cite news|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/suburbs/wilmette/lifestyles/ct-evr-go-robbie-fulks-grammys-tl-0209-20170209-story.html|title=Wilmette's Robbie Fulks up for first two Grammy Awards on Sunday|last=Loerzel|first=Robert|work=chicagotribune.com|access-date=2017-03-15|language=en-US|archive-date=2017-03-16|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170316113742/http://www.chicagotribune.com/suburbs/wilmette/lifestyles/ct-evr-go-robbie-fulks-grammys-tl-0209-20170209-story.html|url-status=live}} == Musical style == [[File:Robbie Fulks - December 2013.jpg|thumb|Robbie Fulks playing a house concert on December 14, 2013]] As a songwriter, Fulks is difficult to categorize.{{cite web|last=Tucker|first=Ken|title=Robbie Fulks: Exhilarating And Bitter On 'Gone Away Backward'|url=https://www.npr.org/2013/09/19/224063426/robbie-fulks-exhilarating-and-bitter-on-gone-away-backward|work=NPR (Fresh Air)|publisher=National Public Radio|access-date=December 27, 2013|date=September 19, 2013|archive-date=December 26, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131226205410/http://www.npr.org/2013/09/19/224063426/robbie-fulks-exhilarating-and-bitter-on-gone-away-backward|url-status=live}} Nathan Rabin of A.V. Club says he "has a genius for twisting and subverting country tropes," and "there's more to Fulks than tomfoolery and glibly satirical lyrics."{{cite web|last=Rabin|first=Nathan|title=Week 37: Robbie Fulks, The Alternative|url=http://www.avclub.com/article/week-37-robbie-fulks-the-alternative-42632|work=AV Club|publisher=The Onion|access-date=December 28, 2013|date=June 29, 2010|archive-date=December 30, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131230232858/http://www.avclub.com/article/week-37-robbie-fulks-the-alternative-42632|url-status=live}} Many of his compositions are silly, funny or spoof songs, such as "Godfrey" ("the sickly, unemployed, amateur children's magician") on the compilation children's album ''The Bottle Let Me Down'', while others are serious country songs.{{cite web|title=Godfrey, the sickly unemployed amateur children's magician|url=http://www.memefirst.com/001334.html|work=MemeFirst|access-date=December 28, 2013|date=January 13, 2006|archive-date=March 2, 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120302090138/http://www.memefirst.com/001334.html|url-status=live}} His music is widely described as either alternative country or folk. Fulks's songwriting often includes humor.{{cite web|last=Varriano|first=Jackie|title=Alt country is funny for Fulks: The longtime musician finally got some recognition with a hard jab at Nashville|url=http://www.registerguard.com/rg/entertainment/30837292-67/fulks-song-music-songs-really.html.csp|work=The Register Guard (Eugene, OR)|access-date=December 27, 2013|date=December 13, 2013}} Peter Applebome of ''The New York Times'' describes his work as "one part artful country, one part artful sendup of country, and one part a little of everything else."{{cite news|last=Applebome|first=Peter|title=MUSIC; It's Off the Map, but It's His Country, Right or Wrong|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2000/10/15/arts/music-it-s-off-the-map-but-it-s-his-country-right-or-wrong.html?pagewanted=all&src=pm|access-date=December 28, 2013|newspaper=The New York Times|date=October 15, 2000|archive-date=January 16, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140116144852/http://www.nytimes.com/2000/10/15/arts/music-it-s-off-the-map-but-it-s-his-country-right-or-wrong.html?pagewanted=all&src=pm|url-status=live}} Fulks has an encyclopedic knowledge of country and pop music and has produced a critically lauded tribute to [[Johnny Paycheck]] called ''Touch My Heart: A Tribute to Johnny Paycheck,'' which was released by [[Sugar Hill Records (bluegrass label)|Sugar Hill Records]] in 2004.{{cite magazine|title=Tributes rarely get better than this, a country music masterpiece.|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/66929/touch-my-heart-a-tribute-to-johnny-paycheck|magazine=Billboard|access-date=December 28, 2013|date=August 21, 2004|archive-date=September 21, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140921102403/http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/66929/touch-my-heart-a-tribute-to-johnny-paycheck|url-status=live}} He considers himself adventurous, and is always willing to try new things and experiment. "Why not push the envelope and see what you are capable of doing rather than recycle the same old ideas over and over again," he said. His musicianship has been called "impeccable".{{cite news|last=Pareles|first=Jon|title=POP REVIEW; Heartbreak and Wordplay|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/05/arts/pop-review-heartbreak-and-wordplay.html|access-date=December 28, 2013|newspaper=The New York Times|date=October 5, 1998|archive-date=January 16, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140116144708/http://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/05/arts/pop-review-heartbreak-and-wordplay.html|url-status=live}} Jim Fusilli of the ''Wall Street Journal'' suggested that "a world in which Fulks isn't a household name is somehow upside down."{{cite news|last=Fusilli|first=Jim|title=Robbie Fulks Goes Back to His Acoustic Roots|url=https://blogs.wsj.com/speakeasy/2013/08/27/robbie-fulks-goes-to-acoustic-roots-for-gone-away-backward/|access-date=December 28, 2013|newspaper=The Wall Street Journal|date=August 27, 2013|archive-date=December 30, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131230232003/http://blogs.wsj.com/speakeasy/2013/08/27/robbie-fulks-goes-to-acoustic-roots-for-gone-away-backward/|url-status=live}} Fulks often plays at [[The Hideout Inn|The Hideout]], a bar and club in Chicago, and has worked long-term residencies there,{{cite news|last=Gendron|first=Bob|title=Fulks honest, unpredictable|url=https://www.chicagotribune.com/2011/07/01/fulks-honest-unpredictable/|access-date=December 27, 2013|newspaper=Chicago Tribune|date=July 1, 2011|archive-date=December 28, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131228015028/http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2011-07-01/entertainment/ct-ott-0701-in-the-works-20110701_1_robbie-fulks-folk-music-irish-fare|url-status=live}}{{cite web|last=Loerzel|first=Robert|title=Robbie Fulks at the Hideout|url=http://www.undergroundbee.com/2010/02/robbie-fulks-at-hideout.html|work=Underground Bee|access-date=December 27, 2013|date=February 9, 2010|archive-date=December 27, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131227175711/http://www.undergroundbee.com/2010/02/robbie-fulks-at-hideout.html|url-status=live}}{{cite news|last=Margasak|first=Peter|title=Robbie Fulks revisits a scorned gem by Bob Dylan|url=http://www.chicagoreader.com/Bleader/archives/2013/05/16/robbie-fulks-revisits-a-scorned-gem-by-bob-dylan|access-date=December 27, 2013|newspaper=Chicago Reader|date=May 16, 2013|archive-date=December 29, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131229074626/http://www.chicagoreader.com/Bleader/archives/2013/05/16/robbie-fulks-revisits-a-scorned-gem-by-bob-dylan|url-status=live}} performing anything from current popular hits to jazz to obscure country masterpieces. He says he rarely performs his own compositions at these shows, preferring to explore other contemporary music that has caught his attention. His live performances feature improvised rearrangements of his own songs, off-the-cuff musical humor, and covers of songs by [[Michael Jackson]], [[Cher]], [[Shania Twain]], and [[The Bangles]], among others. Fulks has co-written with [[Dallas Wayne]] and [[NRBQ]]'s [[Al Anderson (NRBQ)|Al Anderson]] and others. He has a long-time association with engineer [[Steve Albini]] ([[Big Black]], [[Shellac (band)|Shellac]]).{{cite news|last=Margasak|first=Peter|title=Artist on Artist: Robbie Fulks talks to Steve Albini|url=http://www.chicagoreader.com/chicago/robbie-fulks-steve-albini-interview-gone-away-backward/Content?oid=12066394|access-date=January 10, 2014|newspaper=Chicago Reader|date=January 6, 2014|archive-date=January 9, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140109020636/http://www.chicagoreader.com/chicago/robbie-fulks-steve-albini-interview-gone-away-backward/Content?oid=12066394|url-status=live}} == Personal life == Fulks has three children, sons Nicolas, Preston, and Tennessee; and two grandsons, Logan and Miles.{{cite web|last=Goodman|first=Frank|title=A Conversation with Robbie Fulks|url=http://www.puremusic.com/pdf/fulks.pdf|work=PureMusic.com|access-date=December 27, 2013|date=July 2005|archive-date=May 11, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130511153127/http://www.puremusic.com/pdf/fulks.pdf|url-status=live}} His wife is actress [[Donna Jay Fulks]]. Fulks's oldest son, [[List of The Amazing Race (American TV series) contestants|Nicolas Fulks]], and father-in-law, [[List of The Amazing Race (American TV series) contestants|Donald Jerousek]], were contestants on [[The Amazing Race 12|season 12]] of ''[[The Amazing Race (American TV series)|The Amazing Race]]'' and were placed third.{{cite news|last=Pang|first=Kevin|title=Amazing relatives: Locals on 'Race' related to alt-country's Fulks|url=https://www.chicagotribune.com/2008/01/10/amazing-relatives/|access-date=December 27, 2013|newspaper=Chicago Tribune|date=January 10, 2008|archive-date=December 28, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131228031015/http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2008-01-10/features/0801080316_1_robbie-fulks-amazing-race-video|url-status=live}} == Awards == * 2016: [[Grammy Award|Grammy]] nomination, [[Grammy Award for Best Folk Album|Best Folk Album]], for ''[[Upland Stories]]'' * 2016: [[Grammy Award|Grammy]] nomination, [[Grammy Award for Best American Roots Song|Best American Roots Song]], for "Alabama at Night" on ''[[Upland Stories]]'' == Discography == === Solo records === *1996: ''[[Country Love Songs]]'' ([[Bloodshot Records|Bloodshot]]) *1997: ''South Mouth'' (Bloodshot) *1998: ''Let's Kill Saturday Night'' ([[Geffen Records|Geffen]]) *2000: ''[[The Very Best of Robbie Fulks]]'' (Bloodshot) *2001: ''Couples in Trouble'' (Boondoggle) *2001: ''13 Hillbilly Giants'' (Bloodshot) *2004: ''Live at Double Door 1/16/04'' (EMusic Live) *2005: ''[[Georgia Hard]]'' ([[Yep Roc Records|Yep Roc]]) *2007: ''Revenge!'' (Yep Roc Records) *2009: ''50 Vc. Doberman'' 50 song digital release (Boondoggle) *2010: ''Happy: Robbie Fulks Plays the Music of Michael Jackson'' (Boondoggle)/(Yep Roc) *2013: ''Gone Away Backward'' (Bloodshot) *2016: ''[[Upland Stories]]'' (Bloodshot) *2018: ''Revenge of the Doberman'' 53 song digital release (Self-released) *2019: ''16'' (Bloodshot) *2023: ''Bluegrass Vacation'' (Compass) === Contributions, collaborations === * 1994: "Cigarette State" – ''For a Life of Sin: A Compilation of Insurgent Chicago Country'' (Bloodshot) * 1995: "She Took a Lot of Pills (and Died)" – ''Hell-Bent: Insurgent Country Volume 2'' (Bloodshot) * 1997: "Wedding of the Bugs" (studio version) – ''Straight Outta Boone County: Cowboy Songs, Home Songs, Western Songs, Mountain Songs'' (Bloodshot) * 1998: "Across the Alley from the Alamo" – ''The Pine Valley Cosmonauts [[Salute the Majesty of Bob Wills]]: The King of Western Swing'' (Bloodshot) * 1999: "Call of the Wrecking Ball" – ''Poor Little Knitter on the Road: A Tribute to The Knitters'' (Bloodshot) * 2000: "Bloodshot's Turning 5" – ''Down to the Promised Land: 5 Years of Bloodshot Records'' (Bloodshot) * 2002: "Godfrey" – ''The Bottle Let Me Down: Songs for Bumpy Wagon Rides'' (Bloodshot) * 2004: "Tears at the Grand Ol' Opry" – ''Hard-Headed Woman: A Celebration of Wanda Jackson'' (Bloodshot) * 2004: "Shakin' The Blues" (with Gail Davies) – ''Touch My Heart: a Tribute to Johnny Paycheck'' ([[Sugar Hill Records (bluegrass label)|Sugar Hill Records]]); Fulks produced this record also * 2006: "Browns Ferry Blues" – ''Old Town School Songbook: Volume One'' (Bloodshot) * 2006: "Dirty-Mouthed Flo" (live) – ''Bloodied But Unbowed: Bloodshot Records' Life In The Trenches'' (DVD) (Bloodshot) * 2006: "Dirty-Mouthed Flo" (live) – ''Bloodied But Unbowed: The Soundtrack'' (Bloodshot) * 2014: "[[Sally G]]" ([[Paul McCartney]] cover) – ''More Super Hits Of The Seventies'' (Mike-Shell) [[WFMU]] fundraiser CD{{cite web|title=Mike-Shell Presents – More Super Hits of the Seventies!|url=http://michaelshelley.net/2014/|work=Michael Shelley (website)|access-date=February 5, 2014|quote=2014 WFMU Fund Raising Premium CD|archive-date=February 22, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140222071209/http://michaelshelley.net/2014/|url-status=live}} * 2015: ''Jura'' with the mini-[[Mekons]] (Bloodshot) – [[Record Store Day]] vinyl-only release on [[Black Friday (shopping)|Black Friday]]; subsequently in general release{{cite web|title=Mekons & Robbie Fulks: Jura|url=http://www.recordstoreday.com/SpecialRelease/8208|website=[[Record Store Day]]|access-date=November 21, 2015|archive-date=November 30, 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151130093952/http://www.recordstoreday.com/SpecialRelease/8208|url-status=live}} * 2018: ''Wild! Wild! Wild!'' with [[Linda Gail Lewis]] (Bloodshot) * 2019: "Lonely Ain’t Hardly Alive" - ''Too Late to Pray: Defiant Chicago Roots'' (Bloodshot){{cite web |publisher=[[WTTW]] |title=Chicago's Bloodshot Records Celebrates 25th Anniversary |author=Vitali, Marc |date=November 7, 2019 |url=https://news.wttw.com/2019/11/07/chicago-s-bloodshot-records-celebrates-25th-anniversary |access-date=2019-11-26 |archive-date=2019-11-08 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191108035340/https://news.wttw.com/2019/11/07/chicago-s-bloodshot-records-celebrates-25th-anniversary |url-status=live }}{{cite web |publisher=Bloodshot Records |title=Too Late to Pray: Defiant Chicago Roots |date=2019 |url=https://www.bloodshotrecords.com/album/too-late-to-pray |access-date=2019-11-26 |archive-date=2020-04-28 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200428124135/https://www.bloodshotrecords.com/album/too-late-to-pray |url-status=dead }} == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == {{Commons category|nowrap=yes}} * {{Official website|http://robbiefulks.com}} * {{Twitter}} * {{Discogs artist}} * {{AllMusic|id=robbie-fulks-mn0000285164}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Fulks, Robbie}} [[Category:American alternative country singers]] [[Category:American country singer-songwriters]] [[Category:Singers from Chicago]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:1963 births]] [[Category:People from Wilmette, Illinois]] [[Category:Bloodshot Records artists]] [[Category:Country musicians from Illinois]] [[Category:Yep Roc Records artists]] [[Category:Geffen Records artists]] [[Category:Singer-songwriters from Illinois]] [[Category:Columbia College (New York) alumni]]
